p2.p: Residents should remain at home when possible as it is the safest choice. If you do leave your home, keep the following guidelines in mind.

bullets.bullet: Maintain 6ft distance between yourself and people who are not in your hosehold unit.
Wear a mask, scarf, bandana or other facial covering.
Limit face to face interactions with those vulnerable to the coronavirus such as those over 60 or those with underlying health conditions.
Wash hands frequently with soap and water for at least 20 seconds, or use hand sanitizer.
Cover coughs and sneezes with a tissue or fabric or, if not possible, use the sleeve of your shirt or elbow. Do not cough or sneeze into your hand.
Use antibactiral wipes to clean any surface that you have to touch.

p2.p: A map of 'pit stops' and public hand washing stations in San Francisco is available at the link below.
Multple sites across the city are now offering COVID-19 diagnostic testing. Consult the detailed map resource published by the team at DataSF.
Testing is available for any California resident who has one or more syptoms of the virus or who has been in contact with someone who has the virus within the past 14 days.
If you have health insurance, schedule a consultation or test through your healthcare proider.
If you are uninsured, there are multiple test sites within the city where you can still be tested. The DataSF map provides a filter to help you find an elligible site.

All Muni Metro/light rail has been replaced by buses and only certain core routes remain open. Downtown Metro stations remain open to accomodate BART riders. Rapid bus lines are temporarily suspended, but many late night Owl services remain. Refer to MUNIs Core Service Plan to see details of route adjusmtents and closures.

Masks or face coverings are required for all MUNI riders. Backdoor boarding is now required on all buses except for passengers with wheelchairs or other accesibility needs. Muni provides updates at the link below.
Paratransit continues to be available for riders with disabilities. Paratransit riders are also required to wear masks or face coverings while using the service.
Passengers over 65 or with disabilities may also be elligible for an essential trip card. This card provides a limited number of discounted taxi rides each month for essential trips.
There are still over one-thousand restaurants open for takeout or delivery in San Francisco. Eater San Francisco maintains a list of open restaurants here.
For recommendations and curated lists, check out their guide to Bay Area outdoor dining during the pandemic.

Many public recreation facilities have re-opened in the city including playgrounds, tennis courts and most areas of public parks. Social exercise is permitted so long as social distancing can be maintained.

body.h4: COVID-19 Testing Sites in Alameda County

p2.p: Alameda County residents, including those who don’t have insurance, can contact the testing sites listed at the link below. You will not be asked immigration status and you are not required to give insurance information.
Information includes when to get tested, what to look for, and where to go.

bullets.bullet: General Public (most serve both insured and uninsured at no cost).
Members and existing patients of specific health plans or clinics.
Specialty populations (children-only sites, veterans, and individuals experiencing homlessness.)

p2.p: Buses are operating with lower capacity and only allowing a limited number of passengers on each bus. 30’ feeder coach – 6 passengers; 40’ standard coach – 10 passengers; 60’ articulated coach – 16 passengers, and; 44’ double decker coach – 24 passengers.

In addition to social distancing, riders are encouraged to wear a mask on board, covering the nose and mouth, effective immediately. Minimizing trips and reserving transit for essential business will help protect staff members and their families.
Open at 25% capacity or 100 people, whichever is fewer.
50 percent maximum capacity and food courts permitted with indoor dining restrictions.
Full capacity while following retail industry guidance.
25 percent maximum capacity or 100 people, whichever is fewer.
25 percent maximum capacity.
10 percent maximum capacity. Climbing walls are permitted.
This map identifies food distribution sites, COVID-19 testing sites, shelters, hygeine stations, and other services during the COVID-19 shelter in place order.
Updates on parks and trails can be found at the link below.
There is also an interactive map.
